awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Novel Manufacturing Method for Long Length Linear Encoders
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will explore the feasibility of a novel manufacturing method for producing high-accuracy linear encoders (sensors used to perform precision position measurements). The encoder market is expected to grow to $3.7 billion by 2026. The need for high-end automation, smart manufacturing, and continuous device miniaturization puts ever-increasing demands on the accuracy and availability of encoders. The proposed technology will provide more accurate, more robust encoders with shorter lead times and lower prices than currently available solutions.  The proposed research will help establish a core technology required to produce precision encoder gratings for a new generation of incremental and absolute position sensors, helping to secure and diversify the supply chain. 
 
The intellectual merit of this project is to investigate a new method to manufacture encoder gratings. Optical encoder gratings are traditionally produced by contact lithography. The drawbacks of this process are accelerated photomask wear, low yield, sensitivity to contamination, and limited accuracy and resolution. This project is expected to eliminate or significantly improve all of these drawbacks by developing a novel microfabrication approach. Research objectives are to address the unique challenges resulting from the substantial size of the required substrate and the extreme accuracy requirements. Research tasks include construction of an early prototype, characterizing mechanical components, design and optimization of the optical system, and several parametric studies to quantify the performance of the proposed fabrication method.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the NSF Phase I Award period, ZS Instruments made significant progress in developing a novel manufacturing method for high-accuracy optical encoders. Starting from January 1st, 2022, and continuing into 2023, the company successfully completed a small-scale prototype, which serves as a functional technology demonstrator. Substantial attention was dedicated to the design and optimization of the optical system. In addition, an initial version of the control software was also developed. Furthermore, the mechanical design of a full-size system was thoroughly addressed and de-risked to ensure its feasibility and viability.

ZS Instruments also participated in the national NSF I-Corps program during the summer of 2022. This valuable program provided the company with an opportunity to validate the market and engage with prominent industry players, resulting in the identification of several early adopters who expressed strong interest in the optical encoders produced using the newly developed technology.

To assess the performance of the Phase I prototype, multiple studies were conducted, focusing on evaluating the resolution, print quality, and throughput of the system. Rectangular substrates were exposed over a 130 by 4.5 mm area and meticulously characterized. The early prototype, in combination with the developed manufacturing process, exhibited significant advantages and achieved remarkable results:

  • Achieved over an order of magnitude improvement in line-pitch resolution compared to the 20 microns commonly used in modern encoders. The smaller pitch provides a proportionally smaller fundamental resolution, enhancing contamination resistance and improving the encoder`s overall robustness.
  • Lowered line edge defects by more than two-fold compared to typical commercially available encoders. This reduction in defects minimizes harmonic distortions in the encoder signal, resulting in smaller errors within one pitch period. The end benefits to the motion system are higher positioning accuracy with the ability to perform smaller minimum incremental motions, lower stand still jitter, faster settling time, and reduced motor heating.
  • The novel manufacturing technology eliminates the need for expensive full-size photomasks, thereby reducing costs and shortening lead time.
  • The developed fabrication process is both safe and environmentally friendly. It eliminates the use of several hazardous and corrosive chemicals and avoids the generation of chrome-containing liquid waste, which is common in traditional encoder manufacturing.

Overall, ZS Instruments has made substantial strides in their project, achieving key milestones in prototype development, design optimization, performance evaluation, and market validation. The successful outcomes during the Phase I Award period set a strong foundation for future development efforts.
